metadata.title: Anisotropic MXene Aerogels with a Mechanically Tunable Ratio of Electromagnetic Wave Reflection to Absorption

sections.text:
COMMUNICATION
1900267 (1 of 7) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.advopticalmat.de

sections.heading: Anisotropic MXene Aerogels with a Mechanically Tunable
Ratio of Electromagnetic Wave Reflection to Absorption
Meikang Han, Xiaowei Yin,* Kanit Hantanasirisakul, Xinliang Li, Aamir Iqbal,
Christine B. Hatter, Babak Anasori, Chong Min Koo, Takeshi Torita, Yoshito Soda,
Litong Zhang, Laifei Cheng, and Yury Gogotsi*
sections.text:
DOI: 10.1002/adom.201900267
Fast progress of wireless communication techniques and applications, and the trend toward miniaturization and portability of wireless electronic devices lead to increasingly complex electromagnetic (EM) environments. Flexible, lightweight, and efficient electromagnetic interference shielding materials, which can be used in different frequency ranges, are needed for protection against EM pollution.[1,2] In general, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding materials refer to both EM wave reflection and absorption, as incident EM wave on a material surface undergoes reflection, absorption, and transmission. Although conventional EMI shielding materials, such as metals and graphite, possess high EMI shielding ability, it is mainly dominated by reflection.[3] The control of the ratio of EM reflection to absorption for EMI shielding materials is still a tremendous challenge.
Macroporous structures offer an effective route to enhance EM wave absorption capability, owing to inner multiple
scattering and EM field-induced currents that occur on walls and/or struts of pores. Porous metal and carbon-based foams made of Ag nanowires, graphene, and carbon nanotubes have been developed for EMI shielding.[4] Metal foams with high electrical conductivity have excellent EMI shielding effectiveness. However, the high density and easy surface oxidation, which changes the electrical conductivity, limit their practical applications. Additionally, plastic deformation of metals limits their lifetime in flexible electronic devices. Recently, graphenebased porous structures have emerged as promising candidates for EM wave suppression. This potential is attributed to the low density, large specific surface area, high carrier mobility, adjustable pore size, and improved flexibility of graphene foams.[5] However, pure graphene foam architecture that contributes to high-performance EMI shielding capability can only be produced via expensive chemical vapor deposition on a metal template.[6] As an alternative, reduced graphene oxide-based foams have been made using freeze-drying, solvothermal, and template methods.[7,8] Still, the low electrical conductivity and permittivity of reduced graphene oxide drastically decreases EMI shielding effectiveness and increases the material thickness required to achieve adequate protection.
Lightweight and mechanically flexible materials that can provide efficient electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding are highly desirable for protecting portable and smart electronic devices against electromagnetic pollution. Here, the authors report a tunable design of a three-dimensional (3D) porous aerogel structure made of 2D transition metal carbides and a carbonitride (MXene) with a long-range order of aligned lamellar architecture for EMI shielding. Bidirectional freeze-casting of MXene colloidal solutions is used to fabricate robust, compressible and lightweight aerogels, and achieve orientational assembly leading to outstanding EMI shielding performance and tunable ratio of reflection to absorption. EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) of three types of MXene aerogels (Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx) reaches 70.5,

sections.heading: 69.2, and 54.1 dB, respectively, while keeping the compression thickness at
1 mm and a density of only ≈11.0 mg cm−3. The highest specific SE reaches
sections.text:
8818.2 dB cm3 g−1, which is among the best values reported for EMI shielding materials. More importantly, during the compression process of the MXene aerogels, the ratio of electromagnetic wave reflection to absorption increases without noticeable change of the total EMI SE. Compressible MXene aerogels with aligned layers offer an effective approach to control the electromagnetic wave absorption and reflection in EMI shielding materials.
Dr. M. Han, K. Hantanasirisakul, A. Iqbal, C. B. Hatter, Dr. B. Anasori, Prof. Y. Gogotsi A. J. Drexel Nanomaterials Institute and Department of Materials Science and Engineering Drexel University Philadelphia, PA 19104, USA E-mail: Gogotsi@drexel.edu Prof. X. Yin, X. Li, Prof. L. Zhang, Prof. L. Cheng Science and Technology on Thermostructural Composite Materials Laboratory Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi’an, Shaanxi 710072, China E-mail: yinxw@nwpu.edu.cn A. Iqbal, Prof. C. M. Koo Materials Architecturing Research Center Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) Seoul 02792, Republic of Korea T. Torita, Y. Soda Murata Manufacturing Co., Ltd Ltd. 10-1-1, Higashikotari, Nagaokakyo-shi, Kyoto 617-8555, Japan

sections.heading: Electromagnetic Wave Shielding
sections.text:
Adv. Optical Mater. 2019, 1900267
www.advancedsciencenews.com
www.advopticalmat.de
2D transition metal carbides and carbonitrides (MXenes) have been proven to be outstanding EMI shielding materials.[9] MXene flakes have high electrical conductivity, and their surfaces are covered by –OH, –O, and –F terminations, which make them hydrophilic and solution-processable. Typically, EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) of Ti3C2Tx (Tx represents the surface terminations) films reaches 45 dB at a thickness of 1.5 µm, which is the best performance among all materials so far.[1] In spite of its outstanding performance, the metallic properties of dense Ti3C2Tx films lead to complete reflection of the incident EM wave. Some impressive progress has been made to control EMI shielding performance of Ti3C2Tx. For example, Liu et al. reported that EMI SE of porous hydrophobic MXene films which are modified by hydrazine reached ≈70 dB at a thickness of 60 µm.[10] Only very recently a first report on Ti3C2Tx-based aerogels for EMI shielding was published, showing that EMI SE of MXene foam reached ≈60 dB at a density of 20.7 mg cm−3.[11] MXene foams are very promising to achieve the tunable ratio of absorption to reflection for incident EM wave, and need to be explored further.
Here, we report on additive-free, aligned, lamellar, and macroporous MXene aerogels with long-range order through the assembly of a series of MXenes (Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx) using a bidirectional freeze-casting technique, as shown in Figure 1. MXene aerogels with lamination and inner cellular architecture exhibit the advantages of both metals- and graphene-based sponges, including good compressibility, low specific weight, high electrical conductivity, and excellent EMI shielding performance. The electrical resistance of MXene aerogels remains stable after 20 compressive cycles at 50% strain. EMI SE of Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx aerogels with a density of ≈11.0 mg cm−3 reach 70.5, 69.2, and 54.1 dB, respectively. Particularly, we discuss the mechanism of the changing ratio of absorption to reflection with the compression of MXene aerogels. In addition to the outstanding EMI shielding performance of MXene aerogels, we propose a general strategy for adjusting the absorption and reflection against incident EM wave for flexible EMI shielding materials.
The prepared colloidal solutions contained few-layer and single-layer MXene flakes. Figure 2a shows a scanning
electron microscope (SEM) image of a single Ti3C2Tx flake with a lateral size of ≈10 µm on an alumina membrane. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image (Figure 2b) showing a Ti3C2Tx flake with wrinkles indicates that the as-synthesized Ti3C2Tx flakes were successfully delaminated via mild etching using a mixture of HCl and LiF. A TEM image in Figure 2c suggests some of the flakes have few MXene layers. The as-produced Ti2CTx and Ti3CNTx flakes also formed few-layer sheets after delamination, as shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information. This was further confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of MXene films (Figure S2, Supporting Information). The prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ ≈7° corresponds to the (002) reflections of Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx, indicating the complete exfoliation of MXenes.[12]
Freestanding and lightweight MXene aerogels with anisotropic structure and flakes aligned on the centimeter scale were obtained after freeze-drying aqueous colloidal solution of MXene flakes in dual directions (Figure 2d). As shown in Figure 2e, as-prepared Ti3C2Tx aerogel has a lamellar structure with a long-range order, which is distinguished from the random architecture of Ti3C2Tx aerogel prepared using the conventional freeze-drying technique (Figure S3, Supporting Information). In the bidirectional freeze-casting process, dual temperature gradients in both horizontal and vertical directions were generated simultaneously, due to the presence of a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) wedge with a slope angle between the copper plate and MXene colloidal solution (Figure 1). Bidirectional growth of ice crystals arranges MXene flakes into the aligned lamellar architecture. By increasing the starting concentration of MXene colloidal solution from 6 to 12 mg mL−1, the resulting bidirectional aerogels become denser (Figure 2f–h). When the concentration of Ti3C2Tx solution is low (6 mg mL−1), oriented lamellar layers with lamellae spacing of 100–150 µm and few interconnections are observed (Figure 2f,i). With the increasing concentration of Ti3C2Tx solution (9 mg mL−1), the spacing between lamellae is decreased to ≈50 µm, and many synapses, which are perpendicular to the aligned layers, are found (Figure 2g,j). When the concentration of Ti3C2Tx solution reaches 12 mg mL−1, the interlamellae spacing is further decreased to ≈20 µm. Vertical
MXene layers formed “bridges” that connect the adjacent horizontal layers (Figure 2h,k). The architectural evolution demonstrates a dependence on the concentration of MXene colloidal solution, as shown in Figure 2l. Also, the viscosity of MXene suspension rises with the increasing concentration.[13] This leads to the enhanced alignment and restricts the flowability of hydrophilic 2D flakes. Some of the flakes could be swallowed by the growing ice dendrites.[14,15] The architecture consisting of highly oriented MXene layers and interconnected bridges was further confirmed by the XRD patterns comparison of Ti3C2Tx aerogel before and after rolling (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Two major reflections which are assigned to {110} and {010} plane families can be detected for Ti3C2Tx aerogels, while only {00l} reflections with higher intensity are present in the rolled Ti3C2Tx
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900267 (3 of 7)
www.advopticalmat.de
film. The {110} reflections in the as-produced aerogel confirm that some Ti3C2Tx flakes are not parallel to the surface due to the presence of the vertical bridges between the layers.[16] The disappearance of {110} reflections after rolling shows that the vertical bridges get reoriented parallel to Ti3C2Tx layers, similar to filtered Ti3C2Tx films.
Compressive cycling tests were conducted on Ti3C2Tx aerogels with different densities (5.5, 8.3, and 11.0 mg cm−3) up to the 50% strain. Ti3C2Tx aerogel with a density of 11.0 mg cm−3 presents high resilience when released from the compression normal to the lamellae after 20 cycles (Figure 3a). The maximum stress recovery maintains a stable ratio of ≈84.5% after 5 cycles, and the irreversible deformation ratios are around 16% (Figure 3b). At 37 mg mass, the aerogel sample can support more than 2200 times its own weight without collapsing and recover from the ≈50% deformation (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The broken and buckled MXene bridges will
lead to permanent (irreversible) deformation (Figure S6, Supporting Information). It is worth noting that these as-prepared aerogels with high resilience are additive-free, while polymer binders or supporting skeletons are usually utilized to improve the strength and elasticity of foams.[4b][15,17] This is attributed to the long-range ordered MXene lamellae and vertical supporting MXene bridges. MXene lamellae, as the cell walls, are comprised of oriented and tightly packed MXene flakes with high modulus of elasticity, and render a high compliance in the outof-plane direction.[18]
Compressive performance of Ti3C2Tx aerogels with densities of 5.5 and 8.3 mg cm−3 was tested as well (Figure S7, Supporting Information). The meaured stresses at 50% strain for these samples were 0.74 and 1.06 kPa, respectively, while that of Ti3C2Tx aerogel with a density of 11.0 mg cm−3 is 1.61 kPa. The deformation ratios of Ti3C2Tx aerogels with densities of 5.5, 8.3, and 11.0 mg cm−3 after 20 cycles are 25.7%, 19.0%, and
Adv. Optical Mater. 2019, 1900267
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900267 (4 of 7)
www.advopticalmat.de
16.0%, respectively (Figure 3c). It suggests that the increasing bridge numbers and the decreasing interlayer spacing improve the resilience and strength. MXene samples with a larger number of layers and bridges per unit of volume can store a larger amount of compressive energy and tolerate more stress. In addition, the loading curves of all Ti3C2Tx aerogels show a quasi-elastic region (<30%), which is attributed to the bending and shearing deformations of Ti3C2Tx bridges. The following nonlinear region results from the densification of Ti3C2Tx aerogels due to fracture of bridges.
The electrical resistance of Ti3C2Tx aerogel with a density of 11.0 mg cm−3 was recorded under compression cycles (50% strain), which showed a decrease from 1.94 to 1.58 Ω in the first 5 cycles, and then remained stable over compressingreleasing cycles (Figure 3d) up to at least 20 cycles. The electrical resistance was ≈1.6 Ω after unloading, while the electrical resistance in the compressed state was ≈1.38 Ω at 50% strain. This demonstrates the structural resilience of aligned MXene aerogels that is promising for EMI shielding materials and other flexible devices experiencing eventual deformation.
To evaluate EMI shielding performance of different MXene aerogels, S parameters of Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx aerogels with different densities, whose aligned layers are perpendicular to the incident EM wave, were measured in the X-band range (8.2–12.4 GHz). The results show that total EMI shielding effectiveness (SET) values of all the MXene aerogels are frequencydependent (Figures S8–S10, Supporting Information). The highest SET of Ti2CTx aerogel can reach 82.1 dB at 10.1 GHz at
a density of 11.0 mg cm−3 and a thickness of 1 mm, while those values for Ti3C2Tx and Ti3CNTx aerogels are 76.7 dB at 9.2 GHz and 59 dB at 9.7 GHz (Figure 4a). The average SET values in X-band of Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx aerogels reach 70.5, 69.2, and 54.1 dB, respectively. For Ti3C2Tx aerogels at a thickness of 1 mm, reflection shielding effectiveness (SER) increases from 10.3 to 12.9 dB, and absorption shielding effectiveness (SEA) increases from 34.5 to 57.6 dB when the density increases from 5.5 to 11.0 mg cm−3 (Figure 4b). The corresponding absorptivity (A) and reflectivity (R) power coefficients that present the ratios of absorption and reflection for the incident EM wave were also calculated based on S parameters. As shown in Figure S11a in the Supporting Information, the contribution of absorption decreases while that of reflection is improving with increasing density. This rise in the contribution of reflection may be related to the increasing conductivity of aerogels. SET, SER, and SEA of Ti2CTx and Ti3CNTx aerogels show the same trend with the increasing density (Figures S12a and S13a, Supporting Information). The enhancements of both SER and SEA values can be attributed to the decreasing interlayer spacings and increasing number of bridges in MXene aerogels with increasing density, which leads to the higher conductivity and a larger number of lamellae per unit of volume.
Since the as-prepared aerogels show compressive recovery, EMI SE was measured for aerogels compressed to different thicknesses. Interestingly, the total SE values show few fluctuations in the thickness range from 3 to 1 mm. However, SER values always increase with decreasing thickness, while
Adv. Optical Mater. 2019, 1900267
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900267 (5 of 7)
www.advopticalmat.de
SEA keeps decreasing. For Ti3C2Tx aerogels with a density of 11.0 mg cm−3, SER rises from 6.1 to 12.9 dB, and SEA decreases from 62.4 to 57.6 dB when the sample with a thickness of 3 mm was pressed to 1 mm (Figure 4c). Meanwhile, R increases from 0.78 to 0.94, and A decreases from to 0.22 to 0.06 with reducing the thickness (Figure S11b, Supporting Information). The same behavior can be found in the compressive Ti2CTx and Ti3CNTx aerogels (Figures S12b and S13b, Supporting Information). There are two factors that lead to the increasing ratio of reflection to absorption. First, the electrical resistances of Ti3C2Tx aerogels with different densities show different rates of decrease with increasing compression strain, as shown in Figure 4d. This resistance decrease is responsible for the stronger reflection of the incident EM wave. Second, the inner pores of MXene aerogels become smaller with the decrease of interlamellae spacings after compression, leading to fewer multiple reflections. Thus, MXene aerogels with stable EMI shielding performance and tunable absorption to reflection can be applied in deformation-sensitive devices against EM wave pollution. To compare the produced aerogels with other materials, EMI SE values normalized by thickness (SE/t), specific SE (SSE), and SSE/t of as-prepared MXene aerogels and the reported materials with foam structures have been summarized (details in Table S2, Supporting Information). As shown in Figure 5a, most studies focused on carbon-based foams (graphene, CNTs, carbon fibers, polymer-derived carbon, and others), owing to
Adv. Optical Mater. 2019, 1900267
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900267 (6 of 7)
www.advopticalmat.de
the low density and high electrical conductivity of the carbon materials. Generally, pure carbon foams have lower densities, but the specimens must be thicker to increase EMI SE, such as sugarcane-derived carbon foam with SE value of 51 dB at a thickness of 10 mm.[19] The addition of metals offers an effective approach to improve SE/t, but the density is increased simultaneously. SE/t values of MXene aerogels are superior to those of the listed materials in different categories. Typically, SE/t values of Ti3C2Tx and Ti2CTx aerogels reach 70.5 and 69.2 dB mm−1, which are ≈1.5 times higher than the highest reported values.[20] When comparing SSE and SSE/t values of MXene aerogels with these materials, all MXene aerogels with different densities are among the best performance, as shown in Figure S14 in the Supporting Information. SSE/t value of Ti2CTx with a density of 5.5 mg cm−3 and a thickness of 1 mm reaches 8818.2 dB cm2 g−1, being several times higher than that of other materials reported so far. These results suggest that MXene aerogel films with ultralow density, small thickness, and high EMI SE meet the requirements for protecting electronic devices better than other materials evaluated to date. Also, the extreme value achieved by the less-studied Ti2CTx suggests that other MXenes from more than 30 already available should be evaluated to identify materials with the best performance within the MXene family.
The proposed shielding mechanisms leading to the highperformance EMI shielding of aligned MXene aerogels are schematically shown in Figure 5b. Significantly, the incident EM wave undergoes more absorption in Ti3C2Tx aerogels than Ti3C2Tx films, which reflect >99% of EM waves.[1] The higher absorptivity ratio is mainly attributed to the macroporous structure of MXene aerogels that has a greater impedance match with free space. Apart from the directly reflected EM wave on the aerogel surface, the surviving incident EM wave undergoes multiple reflections/scattering inside the cellular network constructed by horizontally-oriented MXene lamellae and vertical bridges. Furthermore, long-range ordered MXene lamellae consisting of entangled MXene flakes with superb intrinsic conductivity give rise to time-varying EM fields-induced currents, which contribute to conductive loss and convert into heat.[7,10,21] Besides the lamellar structure, MXene flakes themselves play an important role in dissipating EM wave. The abundant surface terminations and native defects of pristine MXenes (Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx) lead to intrinsic dipole polarizations accompanied by the relaxations in an alternating EM field, resulting in EM wave dissipation.[22]
In conclusion, we have fabricated a series of MXene aerogels (Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx) with lamellar architectures and long-range ordering through a bidirectional freeze-casting under dual temperature gradients. In contrast to conventional random aerogels, aligned MXene aerogels maintain a stress recovery of 84.5% and stable electrical resistance after 20 compressing-releasing cycles. The average EMI SE values of Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx aerogels at a thickness of 1 mm reach 70.5, 69.2, and 54.1 dB in the frequency range of 8.2– 12.4 GHz, respectively. The highest SSE/t of Ti2CTx aerogels reaches an extremely high value of 88 182 dB cm2 g−1, owing to the ultralow density (0.0055 g cm−3) and high EMI SE (48.5 dB) of thin films (1 mm). MXene aerogels maintain stable total shielding effectiveness with the increasing ratio of reflection to
absorption under compression from 3 to 1 mm, which is attributed to their 3D skeletons with well-arranged cellular structure. The additive-free MXene aerogels with low specific weight, high compressibility, and high EMI shielding capability can be used to design ultra-light shielding for portable and flexible electronic devices.
Supporting Information Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.

referenceMentions.context: [6] As an alternative, reduced graphene oxide-based foams have been made using freeze-drying, solvothermal, and template methods.[7,8] Still, the low electrical conductivity and permittivity of reduced graphene oxide drastically decreases EMI shielding effectiveness and increases the material thickness required to achieve adequate protection.

Furthermore, long-range ordered MXene lamellae consisting of entangled MXene flakes with superb intrinsic conductivity give rise to time-varying EM fields-induced currents, which contribute to conductive loss and convert into heat.[7,10,21] Besides the lamellar structure, MXene flakes themselves play an important role in dissipating EM wave.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/adom.201900267 Fast progress of wireless communication techniques and applications, and the trend toward miniaturization and portability of wireless electronic devices lead to increasingly complex electromagnetic (EM) environments. Flexible, lightweight, and efficient electromagnetic interference shielding materials, which can be used in different frequency ranges, are needed for protection against EM pollution.[1,2] In general, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding materials refer to both EM wave reflection and absorption, as incident EM wave on a material surface undergoes reflection, absorption, and transmission. Although conventional EMI shielding materials, such as metals and graphite, possess high EMI shielding ability, it is mainly dominated by reflection.[3] The control of the ratio of EM reflection to absorption for EMI shielding materials is still a tremendous challenge. Macroporous structures offer an effective route to enhance EM wave absorption capability, owing to inner multiple scattering and EM field-induced currents that occur on walls and/or struts of pores. Porous metal and carbon-based foams made of Ag nanowires, graphene, and carbon nanotubes have been developed for EMI shielding.[4] Metal foams with high electrical conductivity have excellent EMI shielding effectiveness. However, the high density and easy surface oxidation, which changes the electrical conductivity, limit their practical applications. Additionally, plastic deformation of metals limits their lifetime in flexible electronic devices. Recently, graphenebased porous structures have emerged as promising candidates for EM wave suppression. This potential is attributed to the low density, large specific surface area, high carrier mobility, adjustable pore size, and improved flexibility of graphene foams.[5] However, pure graphene foam architecture that contributes to high-performance EMI shielding capability can only be produced via expensive chemical vapor deposition on a metal template.[6] As an alternative, reduced graphene oxide-based foams have been made using freeze-drying, solvothermal, and template methods.[7,8] Still, the low electrical conductivity and permittivity of reduced graphene oxide drastically decreases EMI shielding effectiveness and increases the material thickness required to achieve adequate protection. Lightweight and mechanically flexible materials that can provide efficient electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding are highly desirable for protecting portable and smart electronic devices against electromagnetic pollution. Here, the authors report a tunable design of a three-dimensional (3D) porous aerogel structure made of 2D transition metal carbides and a carbonitride (MXene) with a long-range order of aligned lamellar architecture for EMI shielding. Bidirectional freeze-casting of MXene colloidal solutions is used to fabricate robust, compressible and lightweight aerogels, and achieve orientational assembly leading to outstanding EMI shielding performance and tunable ratio of reflection to absorption. EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) of three types of MXene aerogels (Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and Ti3CNTx) reaches 70.5, 69.2, and 54.1 dB, respectively, while keeping the compression thickness at 1 mm and a density of only ≈11.0 mg cm−3. The highest specific SE reaches 8818.2 dB cm3 g−1, which is among the best values reported for EMI shielding materials. More importantly, during the compression process of the MXene aerogels, the ratio of electromagnetic wave reflection to absorption increases without noticeable change of the total EMI SE. Compressible MXene aerogels with aligned layers offer an effective approach to control the electromagnetic wave absorption and reflection in EMI shielding materials.
